H0.text: To know how many people take medicines is the reason a doctor's office must keep accurate records of the medicines prescribed for their patients.

H1.text: To keep track of all of the people who are sick is why it is important for a doctor's office to keep accurate records of the medicines prescribed for their patients.

H2.text: To keep track of the next scheduled appointments is why it is important for a doctor's office to keep accurate records of the medicines prescribed for their patients.

H3.text: Knowing if there is a risk for harmful side effects is why a doctor's office must keep accurate records of the medicines prescribed for their patients.

A4.text: The medical record may contain a summary of the patient's current and previous medications as well as any medical allergies.

A5.text: The information contained in the medical record allows health care providers to determine the patient's medical history and provide informed care.

A6.text: The chronology of the onset of the suspected ADR is important, as another substance or factor may be implicated as a cause; co-prescribed medications and underlying psychiatric conditions may be factors in the ADR.

A7.text: The confirmation of adverse events by healthcare professionals increases the value of reports, which helps identify risks of harmful side effects.

A8.text: Accurate medical records allow healthcare providers to determine the chronology of suspected adverse drug reactions, which is critical for identifying causative factors.

A9.text: Important features of modern EHR include automated drug-drug/drug-food interaction checks and allergy checks, standard drug dosages and patient education information.

A10.text: Computerized provider order entry (CPOE), formerly called computerized physician order entry, can reduce medication errors by 80% overall but more importantly decrease harm to patients by 55%.
